Jonathan Oddy Mon, 7 Jun 2004 14:59:30 +0100
> Now I come to the validation process and I have received a number of
> bugs to fix (no big deal) but my question is how much should I drive
> my bug fixing? Normally (prior to abbot) I'd dig about my code to
> locate the appropriate code, create a test case (or cases) to
> highlight the bug and drive the fix appropriately. Now I have a UI
> fault that is easy to reproduce - and I've created a test case using
> abbot to highlight the fault, and can now dig through the code and
> fix it... but... this fault (as with a couple of other UI faults)
> resolves down to a failing implementation of some DocumentListener
> logic.

"Real" (complex, non-trivial) UIs have this amazing ability to tease
out problems with backends :-)

> So should I (would you) keep TDD the fix via the high level UI test
> case, or drill down and write "lower" level test cases for the
> DocumentListener implementation. The former helps solve the current
> bug, the later also fixes the bug but has better coverage of the
> listener (which could be/is reused)? Or should I duplicate the test
> to test both the UI working correctly and the listener being
> implemented correctly? I don't like the idea of duplication, and I
> prefer using non UI tool testing (because of the quicker round trip
> effect), but it seems that I probably do need both tests

Fortunately, a rhetorical question:

Jonathan Oddy Mon, 7 Jun 2004 16:13:21 +0100
> Well I've settled on the following:

> 1) Keep the UI test (it drives the UI implementation and tests that
> code from a constrained input perspective).

> 2) Drill down and write specific tests for the underlying logic
> implementation (if applicable).  In this case it was because the 
underlying
> listener didn't have any test code for it.

> 3) Implement (2) and check the fix (1).

> I've chosen this because my current fault *didn't* have any test
> code for (2) and when added - I only got a green bar!? So closer
> inspection of (1) I noted that I was actually wrapping a number of
> DocumentListeners to get the effect I desired - unfortunately I was
> add them in the wrong order. 

You might consider

4) expose API to getEffectDesired() and then testGettingEffectDesired

> So whilst (1) on its own would have worked, I like (2) as well
> because the listener can be used in a number of different ways and
> (1) only tests a specific usage.

Another thing to consider: which is more stable, your UI or your
backend? If the latter, esp if you expect to expose it more ways in
future (e.g. as a service), you should definitely put more test effort
into it--over time you will "spread the overhead." But if your UI is
more stable, and you expect to "forklift-replace" the current backend,
then I might not bother.
